dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC McCOY IS BEING WALKED ACROSS THE COMPOUND BY A UNIFOR GUARD, carrying a riot gun. Other Prisoners around the ya turn and stare as the two men head for the main building.

dialogues.speaker: DOC WALKS DOWN THE BLEAK HALLWAY
dialogues.text: in the corridor, they slap hands... the Guard remains at shoulder. Near the end of the passage another Guard clang open a barred door and allows Doc and the First Guard to enter the room where he stands sentry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG TABLE HAS BEEN SET UP AT THE HEAD OF THE ROOM, sev Prison Officials and Parol Board Members are seated facin the length of the room. Seated at one end of the table is an Irish looking Man; floridly handsome and a bit overweight, his red hair is beginning to grey. The Nameplate in front of him reads J. BEYNON. Doc enters the room and seats himself near two other PRISONERS, the GUARD stands back against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Another table has been set up; this one near the seated Prisoners, for their LEGAL COUNSELS -- SEVERAL LAWYERS examine papers before them, waiting for the hearing to be A MAN at the center of the large table clears his throat, then begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we can begin... First parole request Carter "Doc" McCoy... is legal counsel present? A MAN rises from behind the lawyers' table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Eugene Stewart representing Mr. McCoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching... taking it all in.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: The Man checks the papers before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice a bored drone) Carter McCoy, one to five years sentence for armed robbery, first offense in the State of Texas, wanted by the State of Ohio for assault with a deadly weapon and armed robbery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State of Ohio has waved jurisdiction, Mr. Chairman. They no longer seek Mr. McCoy in connection with that case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adjusting his papers) That is correct. Very well. Mr. McCoy has served four years of his sentence. Prison record satisfactory. Applied for parole on September 5th of this year... The Chairman lowers the paper, looks across to the lawyer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Remarks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would only again like to call the committee's attention to Mr. McCoy's satisfactory behavior as a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice is taken. He looks down the table at the dark-suited men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) The Board met in closed chambers last week... have you reached a decision regarding Mr. McCoy's request for parole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is taut.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: A Second MAN looks across to the Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seated near Beynon) Request for parole is denied. The prisoner may re-apply in one calendar year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lowers his eyes, then looks up at his lawyer. The lawyer avoids Doc's glance., he shuffles the papers in front of him, begins stuffing them into his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still totally without emotion) Very well. The next request for parole is from John Doty. Is legal counsel present?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Doty is serving five to twelve years for embezzlement of corporate funds.

dialogues.speaker: DOC PLAYING CHESS WITH AN OLD CON IN A BLEAK WORK ROOM -
dialogues.text: torn, magazines, beaten up radio, butt cans filled with s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC AND OTHER PRISONERS RUN OUT OF THE GATE LEADING TO th tractor driven carts that will take them to their work ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC AND WORK PARTY HAVE ALREADY ARRIVED AT THE FOREST and begin to cut, file and burn brush. They are always guarde guards, some on horseback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC LEANS AGAINST A WIRE FENCE CHEWING ON AN OVEN match, watches the other prisoners aimlessly wander around the exercise yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC IS STANDING IN LINE WITH THE OTHER PRISONERS, starchy puddles of food are being ladled out onto the metal trays

dialogues.speaker: DOC WORKING WITH SEVERAL PRISONERS, ALL OF THEM ON THEIR
dialogues.text: HANDS AND KNEES, cleaning a long line of open, filthy toilets... a Guard stands nearby.

dialogues.speaker: DOC SHOWERING IN AN OPEN STALL WITH TWENTY MEN
dialogues.text: coarse soap and brownish yellow water... Doc has an Ameri Eagle tattooed on one shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: A SENTRY TOWER
dialogues.text: A GUARD LOOKS OUT OVER THE EMPTY EXERCISE YARD... buildin containing bleak cell blocks stand beyond the open compou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WARDER JANGLES HIS KEY RING AS HE PASSES BY THE IRON do cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC AND OTHERS WORKING. THE NOISE OF MACHINERY IS deafeni The clatter of the constantly working parts is maddening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC LIES ACROSS A SMALL COT WITHIN HIS SHADOW-CROSSED cel He works carefully at a toothpick suspension bridge. Doc glues the final pieces into place...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Around the cubicle his personal effects can be seen, a picture of an attractive woman, several battered paperbac Doc continues looking at the bridge... then suddenly begi smashing it to pieces with his right fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC IS SEATED... WAITING. CAROL enters the darkened room seats herself opposite Doc. They are separated by a wide table and net of wire meshing that springs upward from mi point between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile, she wants the moment to be an upper) Hello, Doc. He simply stares back at her. Carol's finely honed featur compliment a face that at first glance is pretty,at a sec glance shows willful strength. Doc continues looking at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Doc is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been raining a lot the last few days. Doc is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. I've got to get out now. Get to Beynon, tell him I'm for sale. His price. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it now. She hesitates, tries to touch him through the mesh. Gets and leaves. Doc remains unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL ENTERS A LEGAL OFFICE, WEARING A SOFT BILLOWY dress She looks very good. A middle aged SECRETARY looks up at Carol. A short baldin man (THE ACCOUNTANT) in his forties works at a large desk across the room from the Secretary. He seems totally occu with his bookwork.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE ACCOUNTANT THREE MEN ARE SEATED ON A DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: They are dressed casually; by the look of them they might anything at all but all three have commonality; they are professionals. HAYHOE - Thirty years old, buck teeth and blue eyes, a bi ender. CULLY - Well padded strength, large hands and wrists that out of his buttoned shirtsleeves... SWAIN - a little older and a little smarter than the othe two, his narrow features allow no warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECRETARY Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see Jack Beynon. The Accountant nods to the Secretary, she points Carol towards a door leading to an inner office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go right in, Mrs. McCoy.

dialogues.speaker: DOC AND CAROL
dialogues.text: bed... his hand touching the soft white skin beneath her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class - regular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Doc McCoy's old lady.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cully looks startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Carol Ainsley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor took out McGovern for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She only rides winning - Class easy class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S LIPS
dialogues.text: pressed against a man's neck. She kisses, then bites a ti portion of skin. BACK TO BEYNON'S OFFICE. HE IS POURING A DRINK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Mrs. McCoy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to talk about my husband, Mr. Beynon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the good Doctor comes up again. (then) Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asked me to come and see you. Beynon looks at her... then lets their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing her a drink) Why? Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think you can.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN'S FINGERS STARING AT THE ANKLET ON THE WOMAN'S LEG
dialogues.text: drawing an imaginary line upward... a woman's hand wearin wedding ring comes up to meet it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A UNIFORMED GUARD LEADS DOC DOWN THE HALLWAY, they turn a corner and go into a small private room, Doc is now dress in civilian clothes. Doc catches sight of himself in a small mirror. He stops looking uncertainly at the image... and then moves on wit the guard.

dialogues.speaker: DOC EXITS THE PRISON AND STANDS WAITING NEAR THE AUTO GAT
dialogues.text: He looks down the two-lane blacktop road that runs along edge of the penitentiary... Doc turns, looks again at the prison... four years is a long time. A dark Caddy is parked down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ACCOUNTANT OR SWAIN SITS BEHIND THE WHEEL. He stares Doc. Doc crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Beynon will see you the day after tomorrow 12:30 at the River Walk. He gestures and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: DOC IS STILL WAITING
dialogues.text: He leans against a low stone wall that lines the entrance way... The duffel bag rests beside him. A late model Ford approaches, stops near Doc... the passe side door opens from the inside... Carol is driving... Do and Carol look at one another, their eyes holding several moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) I'm a lot better off than I was an hour ago. They look at each other for a moment. Carol leans forward Doc, inhibited by the closeness of the prison walls, kiss her lightly, but with affection...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My license expired, let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... She starts the car, slips it into gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FORD MOVES ALONG THE DESERTED ROADSIDE, crossing the border and passing into the State of Texas.

dialogues.speaker: DOC ALTERNATELY STARES AT THE PASSING SCENERY, THEN BACK
dialogues.text: Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I was late... I got my hair done... the girl was slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks fine. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to take a walk. He smiles, then reaches over and gently touches a strand Carol's hair.

dialogues.speaker: THEY PARK THE CAR AND EXIT. DOC MOVES A LITTLE AHEAD OF
dialogues.text: Carol. He sits on the bank watching the kids play.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOYS SWING ON A ROPE THAT HANGS OVER THE PALLS
dialogues.text: COLLEGE KIDS, SOME ARE SWIMMING, SOME STUDYING, SOME just grooving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moments. Carol starts to speak but doesn't. He is preoccupied, lost in his own thoughts. Finally he stands, looking down at her. He slowly takes o his coat, folds it, lays it on the grass, then turns and starts walking towards a tree. Suddenly he takes off his shoes, breaks into a run and di for the rope. CAROL IS ALREADY ON HER FEET, HER SWEATER OFF, SHOES kick aside, she runs after him and hits the water with an awkw splash. She is a brief second behind him. THEY COME UP TOGETHER, AND HE LAUGHS WITH THE PURE JOY of being free and alive. She joins him, in his laughter and their arms around each other, they turn as they are swept down stream.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH AN OPEN WINDOW A PORTION OF THE EXTERIOR BUILDING
dialogues.text: BE SEEN... The interior is cozy and Carol. Carol has live here almost two years. On the wall there is a poster (whi will be on the wall of every room that they stay in from on).

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Around the room are drying clothes. Carol is ironing with steam iron. Doc is sitting at a table with a Colt .45 in front of him a .32 automatic. He is field stripping. There is a bowl o peaches on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the poster) It doesn't look like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? You've never been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been there every day for the last four years. She crosses to him and gives him a hug, then returns to h ironing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Beynon got set up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small town, small bank, big money. She holds up some 11 by 14 photographs in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing my homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like old times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than old times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. I am not looking forward to another stretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a mistake. I'll never make another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Where did you get them developed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assumed name... Houston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: RAFTER A MOMENT
dialogues.text: How much is the score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Beynon's got a long arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) What do you want for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whisky and a peach. She laughs softly, and goes to a cupboard and takes out f bottles of whisky, four glasses and a bowl of ice. Doc sm at her and begins sampling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Doc eats a peach with a sharp knife) How does it taste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the way I remembered. Doc reaches across the table and touches her hand gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good... Made a quick trip to Oregon, saw my brother and the kids. Figured it would be my last chance, unless they wanted to travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Estelle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatter... some things never change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's been boring since you found me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) That's not all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's been a long time. A pause. He continues stroking her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go out much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After four years and now the question comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't handle it then. Now I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with warmth and a smile) I'm still here, Doc. He stands, kisses her gently. She stands and they move to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: THEY ENTER THE BEDROOM AND SIT SIDE BY SIDE ON THE DOUBLE
dialogues.text: bed. They both sit rigidly. Doc's eyes are on Carol, she stares vacantly expectant. Doc begins to unbutton her blouse, it comes undone with agonizing slowness... Carol pulls her shoulders back help Doc drop the garment down to her waist. Doc hesitates, then carefully touches her shoulder... her hair... he kisses her... Doc gently eases himself away fr Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he is very tight) Oh Christ... He again moves close... Doc reaches around to unsnap her as Carol places both of her arms around him, holding him tightly...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doc unsnaps the top fastener, the second one catches, rem unyielding... He closes his eyes for a second... The pres of the moment is again too intense for Doc. Once more he pulls gently away from her. Carol looks at him, her eyes reassuring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I guess I'm kind of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining the obvious) It's just been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got time. We've got a lot of time. I can help you. She stands, begins to remove her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... give me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. She sits beside him again, takes his hand in hers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm just as nervous as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. They look at one another. A pause. He kisses her; their embrace pulls them back across the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let me make you feel good, Doctor. But she has little chance as he begins to make love to he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than I remembered.

dialogues.speaker: DOC WEARING A ROBE IS COOKING EGGS AND DRINKING WHISKY. C
dialogues.text: enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to fix you breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought you a lot of new things. She exits and returns with some clothes. He looks at them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I think I'll stick with what I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. They start eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does Beynon get? A pause. Carol looks directly at Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $250,000 right off the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he straight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the parole, didn't you? He picks up a fork and looks through it, as if it is pris bars. She takes his hand and gently takes the fork from h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks again. (then) I 'm glad you waited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) I couldn't have... much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I got you out. Didn't I, Doc. I did it. I got you out. Carol begins to laugh softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you laughing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I laugh when I feel happy. Sometimes just thinking of you made me laugh. I had a lot of that. And other times that wasn't enough. I had a lot of that too. I know you find it hard to believe, I'm happy just loving you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sometimes I cried a lot too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to smile) I didn't. I just waited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply moved) Want to cry now? Doc smiling, still holding her hand, leads her from the table. THEY CAN'T KEEP THEIR HANDS OFF EACH OTHER AND LAUGHING w complete release they half carry each other into the bedr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, just a pleasant way to have lunch. Doc sits. Pedal boats cut through the water in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to see you in civilian clothes. The Accountant and Swain are with Beynon in the boat. Apa from them two pedal boats come up behind Beynon's boat. C and Hayhoe are in one, and two other men are pedalling al in a boat numbered 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All it takes is a long arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to judge how these things happen. The Parole Board almost never reverses their decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) I guess it was because I was a model prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the only time you and I meet in public. Any business with me, handle it with him... Beynon nods toward the Accountant. He then turns and gest toward the other two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're back with your own people now. Got you some professionals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat, hard) I get my own help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet strength) You run the job, but I run the show. You got two weeks to set it up. It's not a big bank but it handles cash deposits for an o company... half a million... it's a family thing, the bro of the bank director is on the board of directors at Con- Oil... Beacon City. Beynon nods to the two men and they immediately begin to approach in their paddle boat. RUDY BUTLER -- hard eyes and an easy smile; obviously a h gun... PRANK JACKSON -- young, mid-twenties, ruddy face and blon hair; a small man with blank, insensitive features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods to Cully, Swain and Hayhoe) What about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're mine. The one with the moustache is my brother. They stay out of it. We stay clean. As the two men arrive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Rudy Butler, Frank Jackson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rudy) I heard about you. You work with Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of touch. Cops blew him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I got out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jackson) What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was backup man on a payroll job. (as Doc looks hard at him) I hit some liquor stores... I drive good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, (to Beynon) You're working on the passports... (as Beynon nods) ... and visas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will be ready. You guys do your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) I'll take care of my end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) Stay clean.

dialogues.speaker: THREE TRIPODS HAVE BEEN SET UP NEAR THE HEAVILY CURTAINED
dialogues.text: window. On two of them huge sets of binoculars have been racked into place, beside them on a tripod is a lectern w notepad and pencil... Doc and Carol peer through the binoculars then write several notations on the paper. Both Doc and Carol drink coffee from paper cups... the residue of dinners served on hotel trays lie about the ro Doc and Carol share a sandwich as they work.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOWS
dialogues.text: THE BANK CARRIES ON ITS NORMAL MID-DAY ACTIVITY. A Guard enters the building quickly followed by the bank Presiden

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE HOTEL ROOM CAROL AND DOC CONTINUE TO EAT WHIL
dialogues.text: making further notations.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL WEARING INCONSPICUOUS WARDROBE STANDS QUIETLY IN LI
dialogues.text: before a teller's window. As she reaches the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like an application for a checking account. She gets it, moves to:

dialogues.speaker: A TABLE. CAROL MAKES OUT THE APPLICATION AS SHE COOLLY AN
dialogues.text: unobtrusively eyes the bank.

dialogues.speaker: DOC, WEARING HIS SUIT AND GLASSES, STANDING AT A TELLER'S
dialogues.text: window. He moves to the head of the line. He notices a TV camera and a wanted poster showing the fa of wanted bank robbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Could I get change for this fifty please? His eyes alert and probing.

dialogues.speaker: DOC DROPS A LETTER INTO A CORNER MAIL BOX, THEN BUYS A PA
dialogues.text: from a coin dispenser. His eyes find a Beacon City Police idly talking to a citizen... a police car is near the Officer, the driver's side door open... mounted on the da is a shotgun. Doc tucks the paper under his arm and moves down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC WITH BRIEFCASE IS TALKING TO A CIVIL ENGINEER. They b study the detail map of a city sewage system...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with a pair of scissors.

dialogues.speaker: A LARGE ROOM WITHOUT WINDOWS. NEAR THE CENTER SITS A BIG
dialogues.text: table piled with equipment, watch caps, several different colored raincoats, a huge pair of wirecutters, road maps, chemical containers and four sticks of dynamite, four vis and two passports and several padded U.S. Army, super bul proof vests which are not vests at all, more a shield. Rudy and Jackson stand near the table. Carol is seated. S nervously runs her hand along the edge of one of the road maps. Doc is holding one of the vests. The wall behind the table is dominated by diagrams and ma and photos which show the interior of the Beacon City Ban the Bank vault, and several diagrams of the main street o Beacon City, a Beacon City Police car, and a detailed reproduction of the Beacon City main sewage system, inclu electrical wiring, a detailed road map of the town and various photos of a farmhouse and barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bank President, three tellers and one guard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Usually on the right side as you go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nail him first, be careful he doesn't panic and want to shoot somebody. Local police have one car, a rover, shouldn't be in the vicinity at the time we hit unless it's answering an emergency call... if the cop car shows up remember it doesn't have any automatic weapons. Only a shotgun braced on the dashboard. Get into a tight spot, you'll be out of range at forty yards. Then they're down to their side guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For exits off Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should be light traffic that time of day... the Bank Guard carries a .38. These will stop an M.2 at fifty yards.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He throws the vest on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in case someone gets a shot off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worked ten years without one, I don't need one now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. How many bank exits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the vault?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chambers - Reilly. Time lock opens 20 minutes before they start doing business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wire pull over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-inch stuff on a three-number combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'm handling the fine stuff. You're back up all the way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smile) Whatever you need. To Rudy and Jackson, Doc points to the map and farmhouse picture:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going over these. I don't want anybody getting lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding two passports and four visas held together by a rubber band) If we are clean Gollie will take us over at Nogales. If we are hot we'll have to try Laughlin at El Paso. She hands Doc the visas, as she puts the two passports in bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hang on to these. We don't need them till we get to Gollies. Okay. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we going a little hard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a walk-in bank. You don't have to be Dillinger for this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long look at Rudy) Dillinger got killed. Jackson and Rudy begin to exit. The Accountant enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Accountant) Tell Beynon I want no mistakes. I make four phone calls, his boys better pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beynon has to be alone at the drop ... one car at the ranch and that's it. I won't have the money... she won't know where it is until I'm sure it's clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure everybody does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC AND CAROL ARE GETTING READY FOR BED. It is the night before the robbery. Carol stands looking in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how I feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mind's not on guessing games. Carol turns away from the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise you won't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head; smiles) If it's funny I'm going to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like the night before the first day of school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bad? Carol laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised not to laugh. They both laugh. Long beat. Carol gets into bed. Doc is already in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be such a relief not to have to think about it any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting's hard. You never learn how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I've actually gotten tired waiting sometimes... worn out waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you were outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn!t make much difference where you are, if you're waiting, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do. But it is different. (before she can interrupt suddenly up a notch) It's different. (quieting down) We'll be all right tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are always going to be all right tomorrow. I'd like to be all right a few todays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have a lot of those, (easy, embracing her tightly) We're just going to get the money and then go all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling at him) ... and live happily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: DOC'S HANDS
dialogues.text: STICKS of dynamite, two tubes of Naptha, a lot of prima c and one small, dark percussion cap. CAROL SITS BEHIND THE WHEEL OF THE GREY PANEL TRUCK as it prowls smoothly down a brush-lined Central Texas road. Ca drives calmly, professionally...

dialogues.speaker: DOC IS BEHIND CAROL, AT THE BACK OF THE
dialogues.text: VAN. He wears a jacket and watch cap. Doc is squatted down, quickly activating another timing mechanism, checking the clock-face on the bomb against his wristwatch... with a quick, dexterous movement, he places a bomb into the two large grocery bags at his feet. After burying the explosives within each sack, he covers the bombs with crumpled wastepaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grocery bags are then gently shoved forward, resting against the wheel well of the truck. As Doc looks at Carol...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARKED ALONG A SECLUDED PATHWAY, facing the highway which lies a quarter of a mile away. He has on a trench coat buttoned to the neck and his sail watch cap... he stares at the highway. THE PANEL TRUCK SLIDES BY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY CHECKS HIS PISTOL. He shoves the pistol into the sid pocket of his raincoat. Rudy starts the engine... then sl the car into gear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sleepy, traditional municipality...

dialogues.speaker: A DAPPER GENTLEMAN IN HIS EARLY FIFTIES WALKS ALONG THE
dialogues.text: SIDEWALK. He is the PRESIDENT of the First Bank of Beacon City -- nodding to a few passersby, he stops at the front door of the bank, knocks twice. A BANK GUARD opens the do and the Bank President moves inside.

dialogues.speaker: VISIBLE ON THE GLASS DOOR
dialogues.text: sign that reads:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BANK OF BEACON CITY
dialogues.text: Founded 1911 Hours: 9:00 AM to 2:00 PM Weekdays Only

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PRESIDENT SNAPS ON A BANK OF IRRIDESCENT LIGHTS. Seve TELLERS have begun setting up for the day's commerce...

dialogues.speaker: DOC SHIFTS HIS POSITION SLIGHTLY, THEN PULLS HIS .45 OU
dialogues.text: beneath his jacket. Doc breaks out the   clip, examines i snaps it back to position. He replaces   the gun under hi jacket -- the gesture seemingly more a   mannerism than a precaution. A huge pair of tongs and the massive wire cutters rest on floor of the truck near Doc, along with a black leather suitcase. CAROL IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT, Beacon City appears on the horizon through the windshield...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PRESIDENT BEGINS TURNING THE COMBINATION on the massi door as the vault begins to open... RUDY - IN THE BUICK - DRIVING DOWN THE ROADWAY near the outskirts of town. A Texas Highway Patrol car passes, mov in the opposite direction...

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: then checks his watch. A WATCH FACE SHOWS THE TIME AT 8:56. THE WATCH BELONGS TO DOC. He looks expectantly towards Ca THE PANEL TRUCK is now within the commercial district of Beacon City. Rudy's Buick is visible a hundred yards behi THE HAY TRUCK drives off Main Street and into an open fie near a corner of the town. Jackson jumps down out of the cab of the truck and crosse the sidewalk. Rudy's Buick pulls over and Jackson gets into the passeng seat. The Buick then cruises back out onto Main Street... CAROL - IN THE VAN - APPROACHES AN INTERSECTION. Through truck's window a traffic signal appears. RUDY PULLS THE BUICK OFF THE MAIN DRAG and onto a side street. Another turn and he again moves parallel to the M Street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BANK PRESIDENT LEAVES THE VAULT, allowing the heavy d to stand open. A LATTICE-WORK BARRIER made of wrought-iron is pulled acr the vault opening... the Bank President snaps the latch-l closed. CAROL - IN THE PANEL TRUCK. She pulls the van carefully t stop at the intersection as the stoplight blinks red... S turns her eyes back to Doc... DOC, CATCHES HER LOOK, then instantly springs into action reaches down, pulls a hatch-like cover up from the floor the truck, revealing the road below... a portion of a man cover is visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking the words) Two feet forward...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ROLLS THE TRUCK SLIGHTLY FORWARD
dialogues.text: ON THE STREET - SEVERAL CARS can be seen moving up behind panel truck. DOC GRABS THE TONGS, inserts the ends into the manhole co notches. He lifts the tongs and slides the manhole cover forward. Doc drops down through the truck hatchway and in open manhole, carrying the huge cutters with him. As he disappears from sight... 98 RUDY DRIVING ON THE SIDE AVENUE, still moving parallel to Main Street. The Buick is now geographically well forw of the panel truck. Jackson stares at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Rudy makes a sharp left. The car accelerates, its wheels begin to quietly whine. Main Street comes back into view... CAROL WATCHING THE SIGNAL... still red... A MAN IN A PONTIAC eases to a stop behind the panel truck watches the signal. DOC STANDING IN THE SEWER PIPE. He turns on a flashlight, moves ahead. His feet slosh through the six-inch-high mur water.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doc shines the light on several ankle-thick conduit lines that run along the sewer wall... He moves down the dark o corridor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GUARD OPENS THE FRONT DOOR, allowing the morning PATR to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PRESIDENT SMILES UPON SEEING THE CUSTOMERS. He looks to the wood-frame clock on the far wall.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOCK READS 9
dialogues.text: RUDY - IN THE BUICK - MAKES ANOTHER LEFT TURN, now back o Main Street. THE BANK APPEARS A HALF-BLOCK AWAY through the car window Rudy and Jackson pull their watch caps down over their fa the holes cut into the caps are wide enough to recognize disparity between their features... MAIN STREET - THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL has now blinked to green CAROL IS GRINDING AWAY AT THE DEAD ENGINE of the panel truck... THE MAN IN THE PONTIAC leans on his HORN... other cars be him begin to HONK. CAROL LEANS OUT OF THE CAB OF THE PANEL TRUCK and gesture for the cars to pass her. She again GRINDS away at the engine. DOC'S WATCH - SHOWING 9:01. DOC STANDS AT A MASSIVE CONNECTING BOX where four 112 str of the conduit intersect. He puts the wire cutters to the first conduit, grasps the insulated handles and with a crunching POP, he cuts through the conduit with one bite. immediately starts on the next strand. CAROL - ON MAIN STREET - trying to start the engine. THE BUICK SLAMS TO A STOP IN FRONT OF THE BANK. Rudy Il4 Jackson pull open the car doors. DOC CUTTING THE LAST AND LARGEST CONDUIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BANK GUARD is placing a local high school basketball schedule and display into position. SEVERAL PATRONS have formed small lines and are transacti business with the Tellers. The wall clock shows the time at 9:02. RUDY AND JACKSON BURST THROUGH THE GLASS DOOR. They stand shoulder to shoulder, guns extended the full length of th arms. Beneath the mask Rudy's smile is visible. THE BANK GUARD LOOKS UP PROM THE BASKETBALL DISPLAY. His widen... both guns are leveled directly at him... simultaneously the lights go out... THE BANK PRESIDENT DESPERATELY PUSHES THE ALARM BUTTON ne his desk. (INSERT: Button and bell.) Nothing happens. CAROL - ON MAIN STREET - trying to start the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE D.D.S. TORTURES A BALDING PATIENT with a drill. The PATIENT groans, lifts one leg in the air from the pain. When the power goes, the Dentist quizzically raises the d and examines it. The Patient pants in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superior technology, my ass. AN ELECTRIC WEATHER/TIME INDICATOR - above the town squar as the bulbs dim... DOC RUNNING DOWN THE SEWER; stopping at the manhole he scrambles up the permanent ladderway, tossing his wire cutters up into the truck parked over him. CAROL - IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT - again she tries to start t engine. DOC PULLING HIMSELF BACK UP INTO THE VAN with a gymnastic thrust he quickly slides the manhole cover with the tongs CAROL - the engine still won't start. DOC DROPS THE HATCH DOOR back down into place on the floo the truck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping his look to Carol) Okay. CAROL TURNS THE IGNITION SWITCH BACK ON... CAROL - AS THE ENGINE ROARS TO LIFE she engages the gearshift. The truck begins to move forward. Suddenly, th motor does STALL. DOC'S PACE TIGHTENS. The cars behind the van continue HONKING. CAROL - AGAIN GRINDING AWAY AT THE ENGINE. Her lips are compressed into a thin line... After a moment... the moto catches, the truck again moves forward. DOC PICKS UP THE LARGE BLACK SUITCASE from the floor of t panel truck, then begins to move toward the cab and Carol THE PANEL TRUCK WHIPS OFF MAIN STREET and onto a side ave Carol pulls the van up to the curbway, jerking to a stop. DOC IS NOW IN THE FRONT SEAT BESIDE CAROL. He pulls the t door open, then hesitates. He touches her arm, their eyes meet briefly, both their faces warming for a moment. Doc gives her a casual wink then quietly exits the truck.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SIDEWALK
dialogues.text: DOC TURNS AND BEGINS WALKING toward an open alleyway. Beh him the panel truck pulls smoothly away.

dialogues.speaker: WALKING UP THE ALLEY
dialogues.text: He turns again, now moving down a totallydeserted side al The alley opens at one end onto a back street; the opposi end is bounded by a large brick building. Doc removes his pistol from his coat pocket, then approaches a doorway al the side of the brick building. At the last moment he pul down the watch cap mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY DISENGAGES THE LATCH on the side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC KICKS THE DOOR OPEN with a violent jerk of his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY'S GUN IS TRAINED PROM THE BACK OF THE BUILDING over Tellers and Patrons, spread-eagled across the floor. Thei heads are down; several of them are trembling. DOC STANDS HOLDING THE .45 IN ONE HAND, suitcase in the other. He moves into the building, shutting the door behi him. RUDY IS NOW STATIONED NEAR THE FRONT DOOR, ready to inter any incoming bank patrons -- he covers the room from the opposite Jackson. Rudy stands near the Bank Guard's outstretched right hand The Guard's head is bloodied from Rudy's pistol whipping. gun has been kicked against the wall. A short distance aw Rudy is watching. THE BANK PRESIDENT lies face down on the floor, directly under the arc of Jackson's gun... who is continually turn to watch the Guard. DOC QUICKLY CROSSES THE DISTANCE between the side door an the vault, passing the Bank President. He slips the .45 i his jacket side pocket, sets down the suitcase, then eith cuts the lock or picks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) 19 seconds. CAROL - IN THE VAN - She has stopped the panel truck near deserted lot where the hay truck is parked. She drops the bomb-laden grocery bag inside the truckbed. moves back towards the van...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BANK
dialogues.text: DOC FINISHES,, RIPS THE DOOR OPEN, lifts the suitcase and moves into the vault. RUDY LOOKS AT THE BLOODIED GUARD, notes the distance separating the man from his gun. Though unconscious, the Guard's head begins to move. JACKSON HOLDS HIS GUN HAND FULLY EXTENDED. Again he takes brief moment to glance nervously over to the open vault a at the Guard. ANGLES AND INSERTS - THE VAULT is lined with safety depos boxes and large cabinet drawers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A metal table stands off-center, the black suitcase resti on its surface. Doc opens the satchel. He then pulls open of the cabinet drawers nearby and begins tossing banded m pads into the open suitcase. THE BANK PRESIDENT LIES NEAR THE OPEN VAULT. He listens t the SOUNDS of Doc at work. He slightly cranes his neck, trying to get a look at the thief inside the vault. RUDY WATCHING THE FRONT DOOR. A PATRON enters; Rudy gestu with the gun... she hits the deck. JACKSON IS GETTING MORE NERVOUS by the minute... DOC continues working within the vault. THE WOMAN, now on the floor, quietly crying. JACKSON watching the Guard. RUDY watching Jackson. Calling out time. THE BANK GUARD, glassy-eyed, but conscious; he has the lo of a prizefighter who has just suffered a knockout, but i ready for one more round. THE BANK PRESIDENT in his prone position. He looks at Jackson, then to the vault. THE PANEL TRUCK - now at the other end of Main Street. CAROL EXITS THE VAN, carries the second sack to a large rubbish bin in front of an empty store. She deposits the grocery bag... DOC WORKING. The suitcase is now filled. He snaps the fasteners shut . DOC EXITS THE VAULT after withdrawing his .45 from his co pocket . JACKSON SEES DOC LEAVE THE VAULT. He edges around the sid the tellers' cages toward the front of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: DOC MOVES TOWARDS JACKSON'S OLD VANTAGE POINT NEAR THE SI
dialogues.text: DOOR. He passes the bank president.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY NOW WATCHES DOC
dialogues.text: DOC CARRIES THE HEAVY SUITCASE IN HIS LEFT HAND. He gestu to Rudy and Jackson with his pistol while moving towards side door.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON HALF RUNS PASSING RUDY ON HIS WAY TO THE FRONT
dialogues.text: ENTRANCE still watching the Bank Guard.

dialogues.speaker: THE BANK GUARD STILL PUNCH DRUNK PULLS HIMSELF UP TO HIS
dialogues.text: HANDS and knees... the Guard looks at his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: DOC STOPS AT THE KICKED IN SIDE DOOR. HE COVERS THE ENTIR
dialogues.text: bank with his gun.

dialogues.speaker: THE BANK GUARD BEGINS TO CRAWL WITH AGONIZING SLOWNESS
dialogues.text: towards his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Just pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't! JACKSON PULLS THE TRIGGER THREE TIMES. THE BANK GUARD'S BODY turns end-over-end from Jackson's bullets. Some of the bank Patrons SCREAM, others SOB with fright. DOC - His eyes are furious. RUDY AND JACKSON - Rudy shoves Jackson out the front door DOC COVERS THEIR EXIT, then slips out the side door and i the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY GUNS THE BUICK FORWARD, the wheels tearing at the asphalt. Jackson's shoulders rock back as the big car accelerates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC, GUN AND SUITCASE IN HAND, nears the end of the alleyway. CAROL - IN A FORD - suddenly pulls up, filling the roadwa opening. DOC TOSSES THE SUITCASE into the back of the car... then slides the pistol under his coat and slips behind the whe as Carol slides over to the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC PULLS OFF THE WATCH CAP MASK; his face taut. THE FORD SMOKES OFF as Doc kicks it into gear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BUICK STREAKS DOWN THE CENTER OF THE ROADWAY... Two b detonate into fireballs... The Hay truck blazes upward, b instantly igniting. The grange at the opposite end of town becomes an orange- flame inferno... Traffic stalls on the boulevard; Drivers and Pedestrians at the twin blazes. RUDY ZIG ZAGS THE BUICK ALONG. Maneuvering through the stopped traffic. DOC SLIDES THE FORD THROUGH A RIGHT AND LEFT TURN, emergi onto smoke-covered Main Street. The speeding Ford avoids a halting car, then suddenly spi out of control, jumps across the sidewalk, splinters a wo bench, and finally slides in a complete circle across the grass of a small park.

dialogues.speaker: DOC LOOKS MORE THAN A LITTLE EMBARRASSED AS CAROL STARES
dialogues.text: AT him. POLICE CARS ROAR BY THEM.

dialogues.speaker: CLOGGED ROADWAY.
dialogues.text: RUDY DRIVING THROUGH THE BEDLAM. Suddenly a gun appears i his right hand, aimed at Jackson. The pistol roars bucks, roars, bucks again. Jackson is shot through the head twic

dialogues.speaker: THE FORD IS SEVERAL BLOCKS BEHIND RUDY. DOC DOWNSHIFTS
dialogues.text: avoiding stalled cars. Carol grasps at both the seat and dashboard handholds to maintain her balance. THE BUICK EMERGES THROUGH DENSE PLUMES OF SMOKE. Fire lic along the one edge of the sidewalk. RUDY IN THE BUICK HAS NOW ALMOST CLEARED THE TOWN. He tea along the highway... sweating a little but becoming cool. is a pro. His watch cap is now removed. ON THE CURVE - Jackson's body is kicked out of the automo and bounces across the pavement. DOC IN THE FORD POWERS ALONG. He approaches the flaming building, then hits the brakes as ... A BIG DIESEL TRUCK AND TRAILER is coming in the opposite direct ion,, jack-knifes across the road, desperately try to avoid the cars stopped in the middle of the street . DOC, AS THE TRUCK AND TRAILER SUDDENLY APPEAR THROUGH the smoke in front of him, throws the car broadside into a fo wheel drift. Now sideways, then straight, he bumps across sidewalk, over a patio of a house, knocking down two pill through a parking lot, taking with it a large cleaners si then bores back onto the road. RUDY IN THE BUICK STROKING ALONG THE OPEN HIGHWAY. Looks the rear view mirror. RUDY'S POV - THROUGH THE BUICK'S REAR WINDOW, BLACK smoke visible billowing skyward. DOC AND CAROL IN THE FORD NOW DRIVING CALMLY THROUGH the countryside. A police car with light turning and siren wailing passes them, heading for the conflagration in Bea City. Doc's eyes follow the Patrol Car until it disappear from sight. THE BUICK - SERIES OF ANGLES - IT pulls off the highway a bumps down a dirt road. Rudy strains to hold the big car the rutted pathway.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The dirt road becomes a lane. A farm house and barn appear at a clearing. Rudy powers t car up a fairly steep hill, the crest of which is occupie a seemingly abandoned and dilapidated house barn. RUDY JUMPS OUT OF THE BUICK, trots to the front of the ba and pulls the double-doors open. A station wagon with woo panel or the usual painted panel sides can be seen within THE FORD SWEEPS OFF THE HIGHWAY and onto the dirt road. WITHIN THE FORD - DOC IS DRIVING. Carol peels off her sweater. She has worn a faded blouse underneath... She pu a ribbon; her hair falls changing her appearance. RUDY - IN THE BARN - The Buick is now parked near the Sta Wagon. Standing in the shadows, he intently reloads his g then moves towards the large doors of the barn. CAROL - IN THE PASSENGER SEAT OF THE FORD - she watches a Doc drives up the lane... RUDY stands outside the barn as the car approaches. DOC STUDIES RUDY THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD, watching him wip his face with a soiled rag as the car pulls closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC PULLS THE FORD TO A STOP just within the double doors passes Rudy, leaving a clear exit pathway for the getaway station wagon. DOC JUMPS OUT OF THE FORD AS SOON AS the ignition switch cut; Carol a beat behind him on the opposite side. Rudy moves into the archway created by the barn's open do He stands almost in silhouette as the bright sunlight bre around him. Doc snaps open the door of the car, his back turned to Ru He reaches into the back seat and grasps the black suitca not by the middle handle but by each end, as if it contai a great weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking over his shoulder, not looking at Rudy) Where's Jackson? Rudy withdraws the pistol from under his raincoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing his gun lazily at Doc, supremely confident) He didn't make it, Doc... you didn't either. Doc straightens, still holding the suitcase. He starts to turn to Rudy, eyes wide, helpless. Carol fumbles for the in her purse. Rudy extends his arm, ready to begin the execution. Doc swings the suitcase around slowly, seemingly ready to fac Rudy's bullets... then he shoots Rudy in the middle of th chest, Doc's .45 slug driving him backward. Doc has concealed the pistol in his hand with the satchel drops the suitcase with his first shot, FIRES again, blas Rudy in the middle. Two large holes now show at the chest Rudy's raincoat. Rudy is knocked back over the hillock, tumbling down the precipice and into a grassy meadow below. Doc stands at t crest of the hill. He looks down as Rudy's body stops turning. Doc shifts the .45 to his right hand. Rudy's body lies still. DOC TURNS QUICKLY AWAY PROM THE HILLTOP, not giving Rudy' body a second glance. Carol, gun in hand, stands outside barn, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know? Doc doesn't answer, motioning her into the car... the get car... as she starts to change clothes... he reloads. Doc takes a long look at Carol. THEY GET IN THE CAR AND LEAVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL IS DRIVING., tooling comfortably along a country ro Doc is beside her, the suitcase resting in the back seat. After several moments of silence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Jackson panicked and nailed the guard.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Carol takes a deep breath,, then turns her look at the si window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ. Doc leans forward., snaps on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY BUTLER STUMBLES BACK OVER THE CREST OP THE HILLOCK a onto the pathway in front of the barn. His figure is slig grotesque; the raincoat shows two holes from Doc's .45 sl along with considerable dirt and grass stains picked up o his ass-over-tea kettle trip to the bottom of the hill. H obviously in some pain, his walk is a half-lurch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY TURNS ON A RUSTED TAP which sends all-pocketed water gurgling down into a mold-covered trough. Rudy pulls off yellow raincoat, revealing the fact he has worn one of th padded bullet-proof vests. Rudy undoes the vest, lets it to his feet. A huge crimson stain shows at his collarbone RUDY TOUCHES THE BLOOD WITH HIS RIGHT HAND, then looks at hand. Breathing heavily he kneels down and begins to spla the purling water across his face and then he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DIALOGUE COMES ON THE RADIO DESCRIBING THE ROBBERY.
dialogues.text: stolen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got between four and five. Carol starts to open the bag and count. Doc flicks off the radio then cracks open the windwing. D reflectively studies the roadside ahead. They are heading along a comfortable tree and meadowlined thoroughfare tha carries only a sparse amount of traffic. Doc's eyes suddenly narrow on the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now noticing the road) Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat) I see it...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON THE ROAD AHEAD HIGHWAY PATROLMEN HAVE FORMED a traffic barricade. Several cars and trucks are being waved throug the check-point. Wearing sunglasses and Stetson hats, the Uniformed officers make a cursory glance into each passin vehicle. DOC ANALYZES THE SITUATION WITHOUT CHANGING EXPRESSION He slips the station wagon up behind a pickup truck in the l of slowly-passing vehicles. She turns, starts to reach into the back. Doc gently catc her arm, preventing her from moving further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're looking for three men... remember? A YOUNG OFFICER looks into the cab of the pickup, then glances at the empty flatbed. Another PATROLMAN flanks th other side of the truck, repeating the procedure. Several Patrol Cars, fully loaded with additional OFFICERS, are parked nearby. The pickup truck is waved through. The sta wagon rolls up to the check-point. DOC ROLLS DOWN HIS WINDOW. He smiles and nods to the Youn Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) What's the problem? CAROL STUDIES THE OFFICER on her side of the car through closed window... the Officer peers back at her then into rear seat. THE STATION WAGON is waved ahead without a second glance the Patrolman; Doc accelerates away from the roadblock... After a moment, Doc leans forward, snapping on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the barn, behind the wheel of the panel truck, Rud matted black hair is in contrast to his blanched face. He starts the engine, painfully bringing it to a ROAR. The p truck leaps crazily forward, careening across the barn fl SMASHING through the edge of the wooden doors as it burst out into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon rolls down the main street and stops ne an outdoor phone booth at a filling station.

dialogues.speaker: DOC MOVES INSIDE THE PHONE BOOTH CARRYING A FIST-FULL
dialogues.text: of loose change. He begins to dial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'm here. He presses a button on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He presses a button on the intercom. ANOTHER PHONE IN THE OFFICE. HAYHOE PICKS UP THE PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He presses a button on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They checked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the ranch, tell Beynotr we'll leave his cut here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three men dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what. I've got to give him his money. That was our end of the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might be ready to chop us up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it my way. He starts the engine. The station wagon pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Beynon's ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never "been there... When we met it was in his office. Doc looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; hesitant) Do you trust him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just figure the percentages. He wouldn't try a cross until he's got the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's send his cut back -- Just keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we make a mistake., he'll burn us. You make a deal, you're always better keeping your end up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it my way. The wagon continues moving down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO HOURS BEFORE SUNSET. A CHILL SOUTHWEST WIND is blowin The station wagon appears, moving slowly down the roadway bouncing along its rutted surface. AT A SMALL INTERSECTION TWO MAIL BOXES STAND CLOSE to one another. The name Beynon is printed in black paint on one the letter bins. Doc stops the wagon momentarily, looks a the box, then turns down the indicated road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE STATION WAGON clears the crest of a sage brush hill a passes camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC PARKS THE WAGON UNDER A GNARLED COTTONWOOD TREE in fr of the house. As he shuts off the engine, he pulls the .4 out of his coat pocket and shoves it into his waistband. Carol watches the gesture. Doc starts to open the car doo then hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can wait here... I'll wrap it up fast. DOC STEPS OUT OF THE WAGON, then pulls the leather suitca out of the back. He quietly shuts the car door and moves around the side of the house, toward the barn/garage at t rear. HE LOOKS CAREFULLY around the area, his eyes searching fo signs of Beynon's men. Nothing seemingly amiss, he moves toward the front door, tries it, moves away. Doc crosses to the back screen door of the house. After another moment, Doc quietly opens the screen door and ent the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC MOVES THROUGH THE SERVICE PORCH/PANTRY and into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEYNON SITS AT THE LONG KITCHEN TABLE] head on hand, eyes slightly glared... on the checkered oilcloth in front of is a quart bottle of Jim Beam, now half full. He's drinki the sour mash straight with a water chaser. DOC LOOKS STEADILY AT BEYNON for a moment,, sets the suit down on the floor, then crosses to the sink, picks up a g and sits down at the table. Doc pours himself a drink, ta a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, McCoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beynon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swishing the drink) News said two persons killed. Except for a faint thickness of speech, Beynon seems quit sober. Beynon wears a .38 Detective Special C.T.G. in a w leather belly holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three... Rudy got ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you got him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Doc looks at Beynon, notes his gun, then continues stacki the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her? (moving right to the business at hand) Let's c ut up the money, I want to get North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife told me no one would be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hired Jackson and Rudy., not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may nail me into this now, McCoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You know, you and I may be two of a kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. I always do my own work. Beynon smiles and slops three fingers of whiskey into Doc glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. I understand the way you feel. As a matter of fact, you and I might share a great many feelings... Beynon drinks from his glass. Doc continues counting the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps the words) I'm in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still don't get the picture do you? I've always heard what a smart ass operator you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No applause! Beynon pauses a moment. Doc looks steadily across the tab into BeynonTs eyes. Prom beyond there might be the quiet sound of a screen door opening. Beynon gets out of the ch stands beside the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's examine the situation. One, an extremely attractive woman. Then, there's the woman's husband, a skillful bank robber serving a long sentence in prison. Three, a man with political influence, a man who can easily get a parole for a convict... why should he? Beynon sips his glass slowly. Doc's hand edges down towar his waist band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) A simple reason, McCoy. The obvious reason. To rob a bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that life didn't add up to the obvious when I was 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously) What do you add up to here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One. The radio's rappin' about $750^000. We only got a half a million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little more was taken out before. (a beat) My brother's a director of that Bank, Mr. McCoy... I had a few pressing debts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we did that crackerbox... to cover for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles., nodding) The obvious. (as his smile fades) But we are both not interested in that right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (a long beat) My old lady must have made a lot of promises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close... but it takes a hell of a lot more than promises to pull the kind of strings I pulled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet. Doc senses a movement from the shadows behind Beynon. Tur his head slightly, Doc can see Carol standing at the entr to the kitchen. She holds a .32 automatic... the pistol s to be pointed directly at Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have come here when you were eight3 Mr. McCoy. As the gun continues to be pointed directly at Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't think too badly of her... After all, you were in jail a long time and she is a healthy young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (riding over Beynon's words) Get it over with... CAROL FIRES the automatic. The big gun belches the full s in a stuttering EXPLOSION... the slide remains back and i ejected position. BEYNON is driven back to the kitchen wall. He SHRIEKS alo the noise strangely like laughter... his body flattens against the surface, slips downward^ riddled by the big b slugs... Doc stands momentarily frozen against the overtu table. He looks up from Beynon's crumpled body. Carol tak two steps forward, then drops the automatic, sending it clattering and spinning away across the floor. DOC looks at Carol, their eyes find each other. He turns, moves to the sink, splashes water across his face, then f a glass of water from the tap ... drinks it; he looks bac her. CAROL stands watching Doc, tears scream down her cheeks. DOC crosses to Carol, takes her arm, picks up the gun, sp shells and the suitcase, then leads her out of the kitche toward the back door. Beynon's body has slipped from sigh only a few traces of blood show along the white wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy is driving along an open highway. Rudy mouths inane lyrics to the radio, one arm on the wheel, the other clutching his wound. A small sign near a mailbox catches Rudy's eye. He swings the panel truck around in a U-turn, then pulls into the long dirt driveway of an isolated far house.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD CLINTON, D.V.M.
dialogues.text: Practice of Veterinary Medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE STATION WAGON IS PARKED ALONG THE CEMENT ROAD, standi in isolation against the vast Texas b.g. Doc stands away from the car, his back turned to it ... gazing at the horizon. Carol is in the wagon but the passenger side door is open her legs dangle outside the car as she looks steadily at ground. Doc suddenly turns, walks to her and gives her a stinging slap across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid. Tears begin to roll down Carol's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't any way to explain it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent me to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I got out, why didn't you tell me where it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want? Mary Tyler Moore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't start telling the truth... (breaks off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) We keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swain sleeps on the davenport. Cully and Hayhoe sit at tw sides of Beynon's large desk, playing a game of checkers. Hayhoe seems to have Cully badly beaten ... The Accountan enters the room. The block on the wall shows eight o'cloc straight up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. The two men abandon their game. Cully kicks the sofa, awakening Swain. He groggily gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon enters the building. Doc takes a bright orange ticket from an ATTENDANT behind a glass window, th accelerates the wagon up a rampway leading to the upper levels of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: checks his watch momentarily as he prowls the wagon between long rows of automobiles.

dialogues.speaker: THE STATION WAGON'S TIRES
dialogues.text: WHINE through a sweeping turn within the auto park's uppermost level -- through the building's portals the bri morning sun can be seen reflecting off the city's rooftop

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOC PULLS THE WAGON to an abrupt halt within a parking st - at an isolated area. He steps out onto the concrete flooring, slams the door shut. Doc turns away from the car. As he approaches the elevato Doc tears the orange auto park stub into fragments and dr them into a trash bin without missing a stride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL IS STANDING IN A TICKET LINE THAT MOVES slowly fowa She struggles, clutching the heavy, money laden suitcase her oversize purse between both arms. The line of ticket buyers moves forward .just fast enough to make it impract to set the suitcase down. The station is ancient, vaultli Baggage lockers line the perimeter of the lobby and exten off into clumped rows within the wings of the station. CAROL APPROACHES THE TICKET WINDOW. She places the suitca flush against the base of the counter and holds it tightl place with one leg. Carol pops open her purse... a clumsy item in itself... as she lifts her wallet and the elderly ticket-seller looks across to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two day coach tickets -- on the Flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-four fifty-six with tax leaves in forty-five minutes, gate three. Carol pays the tariff, places the tickets into her purse along with the change. Wearily, she labors the satchel ba into her hand, then turns and begins to slowly walk down seemingly acres-wide station promenade. NEAR A PORTICO WITHIN THE MAIN LOBBY, Carol sits uncomfortably on a shiny wooden bench -- the suitcase res on the floor pressed tightly between her ankles. She glan across the promenade walls, her eyes finding:

dialogues.speaker: ON A LOBBY BENCH
dialogues.text: CAROL STARES ACROSS THE ROOM at the scattering of passeng waiting on the wooden seats opposite from her. Carol's nervous boredom increases; she looks down at her pretends to find something wrong with her nails and begin rubbing the cuticles. Carol finally rises impulsively fro the bench, immediately reaching for the brown leather satchel.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAROL WALKS BACK DOWN THE PROMENADE while carrying   the suitcase. As other baggage-laden passengers scurry   arou her, she looks across the arcade, her eyes finding   a gl walled Cocktail Lounge. She hesitates, then begins   to t in that direction. A BANK OF LOCKERS STANDS NEAR THE COCKTAIL LOUNGE. As Car approaches, an elderly WOMAN deposits a coin in one of th numbered lockers, opens the metal door and places a small suitcase inside. Closing and re-locking the door, the Wom quickly moves away. Having noted the woman and more than tired of hauling her burden around the station, Carol ste to the end locker, takes a quarter out of her purse, then studies the time scarred operating instructions on the fa of the locker. She slips the quarter into the slot and op the locker door. As Carol bends to pick up the suitcase, locker door swings closed... She tries to open it but the door has re-locked itself... Carol quite disgusted with h predicament, again sets the suitcase down and pulls a qua out of her change purse. As she again reads the numbered directions, a YOUNG MAN appears at her shoulder. THE MAN IS A PROTOTYPE OF URBAN SLEAZINESS, Doberman Pins features are broken by a weedybrown moustache, a cheap corduroy suit is set off by an oddly matched bow tie. The Man's appearance suggests a kind of drug store dapperness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of tricky, isn't it? She turns, startled by his sudden proximity. In one smoot movement the Dapper Man plucks the quarter from Carol's h deposits it in the slot and swings the locker door open. Setting the heavy suitcase inside, he closes the door, te it to show that it has been re-locked, then removes the key from the lock an puts it into Carol's hand. She is intimidated momentarily the Man's sudden appearance and forcefulness, as well as intentions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toothy grin) No trouble lady. Stepping backward, his canine features disappear into a welter of station activity. Carol watches his receding fi for a moment, then simultaneously placing the key into he purse, she turns and begins moving towards the Cocktail Lounge.

dialogues.speaker: EMPTY CAGES STACKED ALONG A WOODEN WALL
dialogues.text: A YOUNG KITTEN IN A CARDBOARD BOX wrestling with the barr of a .44. A thick veined hand gently rubs the gun over th fur along the cat's neck and backbone. RUDY BUTLER IS PREOCCUPIED WITH THE CAT, giving little attention to the thirtyish Man standing nearby. HAROLD CLINTON puts away a large syringe then snaps shut medical bag. Rudy lies across a cot in one corner of the like Animal Hospital. The large room is lined with stalls cages and pens, many of them vacant. The wonded criminal is bare-chested. A plaster cast has b attached to his left arm and shoulder. FRAN CLINTON SITS ON A HIGH WOODEN STOOL opposite   Rudy. years younger than her husband, tight sweater and   skirt bright scarlet fingernail polish, well-built, her   face suggests sensuality. Fran's bare, milk-white legs   are c under her rumpled skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harold) What's the damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collar bone is broken. No infection yet... the bandages should be changed twice a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a nurse in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going along, oblivious to the implication) The glucose will begin working in half an hour. You'll feel better then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashing a grin despite the pain) The three of us are going to do some traveling. We're going to take your car to El Paso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not possible. We can't leave here... we've got all this.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rudy smiles at Mrs. Clinton. He's never met Fran before, he's known her for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible, Mrs. Clinton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared, but trying to be friendly) Just... tell us what you want. Rudy looks back down at the gun and cat. The following silence is like a scream. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of car do you have, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) A Ford... We have a Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. That's very good. Now Harold, you go out and gas up the Ford, check the oil and tires, we don't want any problems on the road. One more thing... If anybody but you comes back... He points the gun at Mrs. Clinton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) She gets her clock fixed right away... You understand that, Harold? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do what he says, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you come back I'll listen while you make some phone calls, tell a few friends you've got to leave for a week or two... You have to call another Vet about the animals. You tell him to come over and take good care of them starting tomorrow... no slip-ups on that. They got to be looked after...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We really don't have too many friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't think he married well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) That makes things a little easier for us then, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol sits in the bar. A young SOLDIER approaches and sit down at the counter next to her. She is finishing a vodka gimlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a bartender) Beer. Carol glances at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing - begins with the obvious) Guess you have to catch a train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pink-cheeked and freckle-faced, he has to shave maybe twice a week; twenty-one years old, not good-looking (his best feature is his gentle, easy grin) and not a hustler. He just wats to meet a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too patronizing) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too. Got twenty-four days of furlough and I'm goin' home. The soldier's beer arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utah, the Bee-Hive state. I'm from Orem, right near Salt Lake ... Say, you wouldn't happen to be a Mormon, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, neither. There's about twelve people in the state that aren't Mormons and I'm one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That certainly makes you kind of special...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward) Yeah... I guess it does. Carol pushes aside her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (c ont inuing) You wouldn't be taking the train to Salt Lake, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles across to him) No, I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never have any luck. Carol smiles at the soldier. Her features suddenly freeze she glances toward the entrance to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOORWAY
dialogues.text: DOC STANDS LOOKING AT CAROL and the soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really hope you have a nice trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I hope yours is okay, too. Carol moves towards the exit. The soldier quietly sips his beer, his face a bit grim.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL STOPS NEAR DOC.
dialogues.text: They look at each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the suitcase? Carol continues looking at Doc for a moment. Then, suddenly moves past him, leading him out into the m lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL EMERGES FROM THE COCKTAIL LOUNGE followed by Doc. They cross to the lockers. She retrieves the key from her purse and thrusts it into proper slot. It doesn't turn. Puzzled she tries again, th forcing the key, shakes the lock violently. Her eyes widening into a quiet panic, she next looks at t locker number and then the number on the key. Her feature are now totally ashen. She walks up the bank of lockers... puts the key in anoth locker, the door opens, the compartment is empty. Carol turns away from the locker, eyes glazed with fear.. Doc at her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man helped me open it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deceptive calm) And switched keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) It isn't another boyfriend, is it? Carol winces, containing her anger.
